messages.message: I’m trying to deal with Russia to stop you and him from steam rolling west. If you’re willing to turn on Russia I would be open to turning on France.
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'I’m trying to deal with Russia to stop you and him from steam rolling west. If you’re willing to turn on Russia I would be open to turning on France.'.

messages.message: Alright, you make an excellent point.  This year I will turn on Russia.  But you need to fight France. He's on 11, is guaranteed England (eventually), and then you're in to position to stop him from getting another 4 for the solo.  You should demand part of England (or at least BEL) to keep the two of you even.  If he refuses, then you know what he's about.
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'Alright, you make an excellent point.  This year I will turn on Russia.  But you need to fight France. He's on 11, is guaranteed England (eventually), and then you're in to position to stop him from getting another 4 for the solo.  You should demand part of England (or at least BEL) to keep the two of you even.  If he refuses, then you know what he's about.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. Turkey's sudden agreement to turn on Russia and the urgency to have you fight France could be a ploy to divert attention away from their own expansion and potential efforts towards a solo victory. Additionally, their push for you to demand part of England without offering concrete guarantees may indicate an attempt to weaken your position in the game.

messages.message: So, how much of England are you getting?  Or is he letting you take Belgium?

Their focus on your gains without addressing their own intentions raises suspicions about their motives.
